clues: This city is home to a famous tower that sparkles every night.
Known as the 'City of Love' and a hub for fashion and art.
fun_fact: The Eiffel Tower was supposed to be dismantled after 20 years but was saved for radio transmissions.
Paris has only one stop sign in the entire city.
trivia: Paris was originally a Roman city called Lutetia.
Famous for croissants, macarons, and haute couture.

clues: This city has the busiest pedestrian crossing in the world.
A paradise for anime, manga, and tech lovers.
fun_fact: Tokyo was once a small fishing village named Edo.
More than 14 million people live in Tokyo's metropolitan area.
trivia: Home to the world's tallest tower, Tokyo Skytree.
Vending machines here sell everything from snacks to umbrellas.

clues: The city that never sleeps and is home to a giant green lady.
Known for a massive park right in the middle of skyscrapers.
fun_fact: Times Square is named after The New York Times newspaper.
Over 800 languages are spoken here, making it the world's most linguistically diverse city.
trivia: The Empire State Building was once the tallest building in the world.
Originally called New Amsterdam by Dutch settlers.

clues: This ancient city has a famous amphitheater where gladiators fought.
You can toss a coin into a famous fountain here for good luck.
fun_fact: Rome has a museum inside a catacomb with preserved skeletons.
Vatican City, the smallest country in the world, lies within Rome.
trivia: Romans invented concrete and newspapers.
The Colosseum could hold up to 80,000 spectators.

clues: Home to Central Park, Wall Street, and Broadway.
Features a huge statue that was a gift from France.
fun_fact: More pizza shops per square mile than anywhere else in the world.
The Empire State Building has its own zip code.
trivia: NYC’s subway system is one of the oldest and largest in the world.
It was the first capital of the United States.

clues: City near ancient pyramids and a guardian sphinx.
You can sail a boat here on the world's longest river.
fun_fact: The Great Pyramid of Giza is the last surviving wonder of the ancient world.
Cairo is nicknamed the 'City of a Thousand Minarets'.
trivia: Home to the oldest university in the world, Al-Azhar University.
The Nile runs through Cairo, providing lifeblood to the city.

clues: This city is famous for a giant Christ statue atop a mountain.
Known for its colorful Carnival and samba music.
fun_fact: Home to the world's largest urban forest, Tijuca Forest.
Rio's beaches, Copacabana and Ipanema, are world-renowned.
trivia: The name means 'January River' in Portuguese.
Sugarloaf Mountain offers panoramic views of the city.

clues: Home to a world-famous opera house shaped like sails.
Known for a massive harbor bridge often climbed by visitors.
fun_fact: Sydney's Opera House has over 1 million roof tiles.
It’s built around one of the world’s largest natural harbors.
trivia: Sydney was Australia's first British colony.
The city has over 100 beaches.

clues: Home to a clock tower that many mistakenly call Big Ben.
You can ride a giant Ferris wheel here called the Eye.
fun_fact: Big Ben actually refers to the bell, not the clock.
London has hosted the Olympics three times.
trivia: The London Underground is the world’s first metro system.
The Tower of London once housed exotic animals like lions and polar bears.

clues: Home to colorful onion-domed cathedrals.
Features a large square where history has been made.
fun_fact: The Moscow Metro stations are known as 'underground palaces'.
Red Square is not named for its color but for the old Russian word meaning 'beautiful'.
trivia: Moscow is Europe's largest city by population.
Home to the Kremlin, the world's largest medieval fortress.

clues: Home to the world's tallest skyscraper.
Famous for indoor skiing in the middle of a desert.
fun_fact: The Burj Khalifa is 828 meters tall.
Dubai has no permanent rivers.
trivia: Gold vending machines exist in Dubai malls.
It’s home to the world's busiest airport by international passengers.

clues: You can ride a cable car to a flat-topped mountain here.
Located where two oceans almost meet.
fun_fact: Home to the stunning Table Mountain.
Robben Island nearby housed Nelson Mandela during his imprisonment.
trivia: Cape Town was founded in 1652 as a supply station for ships.
You can find African penguins at Boulders Beach.

clues: Known for vibrant street life and golden temples.
Home to the Grand Palace and floating markets.
fun_fact: Bangkok’s full ceremonial name is over 150 characters long.
It’s the world’s most visited city by international tourists.
trivia: Street food in Bangkok is considered among the world's best.
It’s also called 'Krung Thep' by locals, meaning 'City of Angels'.

clues: Famous for its canals and colorful tulip fields.
You can visit the house of a famous diarist here.
fun_fact: Bicycles outnumber people in Amsterdam.
The city has over 100 kilometers of canals.
trivia: Home to the world-renowned Rijksmuseum and Van Gogh Museum.
Built on 11 million wooden poles.

clues: Birthplace of tango dance.
You’ll find colorful houses in La Boca neighborhood here.
fun_fact: Buenos Aires means 'Fair Winds' in Spanish.
The city has the widest avenue in the world, Avenida 9 de Julio.
trivia: The Obelisco is an iconic monument here.
Known as the 'Paris of South America'.

clues: Famous for its skyline and Victoria Peak views.
You can visit a giant Buddha statue on an island nearby.
fun_fact: Has more skyscrapers than any other city in the world.
Hong Kong has one of the world’s longest outdoor escalators.
trivia: Was a British colony until 1997.
The Star Ferry has been running across Victoria Harbour for over 100 years.

clues: Known for trams climbing steep hills.
You can explore a tower overlooking the Atlantic Ocean.
fun_fact: Lisbon is older than Rome by centuries.
The world's oldest bookstore, Bertrand, is located here.
trivia: The famous Pastel de Nata custard tart originates here.
Lisbon survived a massive earthquake in 1755.

clues: Famous for a red bridge often cloaked in fog.
Home to a historic island prison.
fun_fact: The Golden Gate Bridge was once called 'the bridge that couldn't be built'.
Alcatraz Island housed famous criminals like Al Capone.
trivia: The city's cable cars are a National Historic Landmark.
Home to the largest Chinatown outside Asia.

clues: Known for beautiful temples, geishas, and cherry blossoms.
A famous red torii gate rises from the sea nearby.
fun_fact: Kyoto was Japan’s capital for over a millennium.
It has over 1,600 Buddhist temples.
trivia: Kyoto’s Gion District is famous for traditional tea houses.
The city was largely spared from bombing during World War II.

clues: Known for its bustling souks and colorful spices.
You can explore a vast square filled with snake charmers.
fun_fact: Nicknamed the 'Red City' for its blush-colored buildings.
The Jardin Majorelle was once owned by Yves Saint Laurent.
trivia: Founded in 1070 by the Almoravid dynasty.
The Medina of Marrakech is a UNESCO World Heritage site.

clues: This city is famous for a basilica that’s been under construction for over 140 years.
A stroll down La Rambla brings you to colorful markets and street performers.
fun_fact: Barcelona has 9 UNESCO World Heritage Sites.
The city is home to the largest football stadium in Europe, Camp Nou.
trivia: The architect Antoni Gaudí designed many of the city’s landmarks.
Barcelona was the first city awarded a Royal Gold Medal for architecture.

clues: This city has no cars; you get around by canals and boats.
Famous for a grand masquerade carnival and gondola rides.
fun_fact: Venice is made up of 118 islands connected by over 400 bridges.
It is slowly sinking at a rate of 1–2 millimeters per year.
trivia: St. Mark's Basilica is covered in golden mosaics.
The Rialto Bridge is the oldest of the four bridges spanning the Grand Canal.

clues: Home to the famous Hollywood sign and Walk of Fame.
Known as the City of Angels and the entertainment capital of the world.
fun_fact: Los Angeles has the largest Thai population outside of Thailand.
The Getty Center in LA is free to the public and features stunning architecture.
trivia: Griffith Park is one of the largest urban parks in North America.
The city’s original name was 'El Pueblo de Nuestra Señora la Reina de los Ángeles.'

clues: Known as the 'Windy City' and famous for deep-dish pizza.
You can stand on a glass platform over 1,000 feet above ground here.
fun_fact: The world's first skyscraper was built in Chicago in 1885.
The Chicago River is dyed green every St. Patrick’s Day.
trivia: Home to the first-ever Ferris Wheel, built in 1893.
The Art Institute of Chicago houses one of the largest collections of Impressionist art.

clues: A city where you can visit two continents in one day.
Known for a massive domed cathedral turned mosque turned museum.
fun_fact: Istanbul was formerly known as Byzantium and Constantinople.
It’s the only city in the world straddling two continents: Europe and Asia.
trivia: The Grand Bazaar has over 4,000 shops and is one of the oldest markets in the world.
The Bosphorus Strait connects the Black Sea to the Sea of Marmara.

clues: You can find the ancient Parthenon atop a rocky hill here.
Known as the birthplace of democracy and Western philosophy.
fun_fact: Athens is one of the oldest continuously inhabited cities in the world, over 3,400 years old.
The Olympic Games were revived here in 1896.
trivia: The Acropolis is visible from almost anywhere in the city.
Athens has more theatrical stages than any other city in the world.

clues: This city was once divided by a famous wall.
Famous for its Brandenburg Gate and vibrant art scene.
fun_fact: Berlin has more bridges than Venice, around 1,700!
The Berlin Wall fell in 1989, symbolizing the end of the Cold War.
trivia: Berlin is nine times bigger than Paris but has fewer people.
The city’s zoological garden is one of the largest and most diverse in the world.

clues: Home to the Prado Museum and sprawling royal palace.
Famous for vibrant plazas, late-night tapas, and flamenco dancing.
fun_fact: Madrid’s El Retiro Park was originally a royal retreat.
The city’s name may come from the Arabic 'Magerit' meaning 'place of water.'
trivia: Puerta del Sol is the symbolic center of Spain.
Real Madrid is one of the world’s most famous football clubs.

clues: Home to a tower where you can 'EdgeWalk' on the outside ledge.
Known for its diversity, it’s sometimes called 'the 6ix.'
fun_fact: Toronto has over 140 languages spoken, making it one of the most multicultural cities.
The CN Tower was once the world's tallest free-standing structure.
trivia: Toronto’s PATH is the largest underground shopping complex in the world.
The city hosts the Toronto International Film Festival, one of the largest publicly attended film festivals.

clues: Famous for its pastel-colored Art Deco buildings and sunny beaches.
Known as the 'Magic City' for its rapid growth and nightlife.
fun_fact: Miami is the only major U.S. city founded by a woman.
It has the largest collection of Art Deco architecture in the world.
trivia: Everglades National Park, nearby, is home to rare species like the Florida panther.
Miami is nicknamed the 'Cruise Capital of the World.'

clues: Home to futuristic skyscrapers and ancient palaces.
Known for K-pop, high-speed internet, and vibrant street food.
fun_fact: Seoul's metro system is one of the largest and busiest in the world.
The city is surrounded by mountains, offering scenic hikes.
trivia: The Han River runs through the heart of Seoul.
Seoul was originally called 'Hanseong.'

clues: Known for futuristic gardens with giant tree-like structures.
You can visit a hotel with a boat-shaped infinity pool on its roof.
fun_fact: Singapore is one of the world’s greenest cities despite its urban skyline.
It’s a city-state smaller than New York City but packed with culture.
trivia: Chewing gum is banned for sale in Singapore.
The name 'Singapore' comes from 'Singapura,' meaning 'Lion City.'

clues: Home to twin towers that were once the tallest in the world.
Known for bustling markets, colonial architecture, and modern skyscrapers.
fun_fact: The Petronas Towers are linked by a skybridge at the 41st and 42nd floors.
Kuala Lumpur means 'muddy confluence' in Malay.
trivia: The Batu Caves nearby feature colorful temples inside limestone caves.
KL Sentral is Southeast Asia’s largest train station.

clues: Known for a famous astronomical clock and fairy-tale castle.
Nicknamed 'The City of a Hundred Spires.'
fun_fact: Prague Castle is the largest ancient castle complex in the world.
The Charles Bridge has stood for over 600 years.
trivia: The city was untouched by WWII bombing, preserving its historic center.
Kafka, a famous writer, was born here.

clues: The city of waltz, imperial palaces, and coffeehouses.
Birthplace of classical music legends like Mozart and Beethoven.
fun_fact: Vienna has been ranked among the world's most livable cities for many years.
The famous Sachertorte chocolate cake originated here.
trivia: Home to the world’s oldest zoo, Tiergarten Schönbrunn.
The city has over 1,500 coffeehouses with deep cultural traditions.

clues: The birthplace of the Renaissance and home to a famous red-domed cathedral.
This city hosts the Uffizi Gallery, filled with masterpieces.
fun_fact: Florence was the first city in Europe to have paved streets.
The Ponte Vecchio bridge is famous for its shops built along it.
trivia: The Medici family ruled Florence for centuries, influencing art and politics.
Michelangelo's David was sculpted and displayed here.

clues: A city split by the Danube River into two parts: Buda and Pest.
Famous for thermal baths and a parliament building lit up at night.
fun_fact: Budapest has over 100 natural thermal springs.
The Chain Bridge connects the Buda and Pest sides of the city.
trivia: The Parliament building is the third-largest in the world.
The city is nicknamed the 'Pearl of the Danube.'

clues: Home to a futuristic tower known as the Space Needle.
Famous for rainy days, coffee culture, and tech giants.
fun_fact: Starbucks opened its first store here in 1971.
Seattle has the largest ferry system in the United States.
trivia: Mount Rainier is visible from the city on clear days.
Pike Place Market has been running continuously since 1907.

clues: A coastal city surrounded by mountains and ocean.
You can walk across a famous suspension bridge here.
fun_fact: Vancouver is one of the few major cities where you can ski and sail in the same day.
It has been ranked as one of the most livable cities globally.
trivia: The Capilano Suspension Bridge stretches 137 meters across a canyon.
Vancouver hosted the 2010 Winter Olympics with Whistler.

clues: Known for its vibrant laneways and coffee culture.
Hosts one of the world's biggest tennis tournaments every January.
fun_fact: Melbourne was once the richest city in the world during the gold rush.
It is home to the largest tram network in the world.
trivia: Often called Australia's cultural capital.
The city’s weather is famous for having 'four seasons in one day.'

clues: A city where old Mughal architecture meets a modern capital region.
You can visit the towering red sandstone minaret known as Qutub Minar.
fun_fact: Delhi is the second most populous city in India after Mumbai.
It hosts the largest spice market in Asia at Khari Baoli.
trivia: Red Fort and Humayun's Tomb are UNESCO World Heritage Sites.
The Delhi Metro is one of the largest and most efficient in Asia.

clues: Known as the financial capital of India and home to Bollywood.
You can visit the iconic Gateway of India overlooking the sea.
fun_fact: Mumbai was originally a group of seven islands.
It is home to Antilia, one of the most expensive private residences in the world.
trivia: The Dabbawala lunch delivery system is studied in business schools worldwide.
Mumbai’s Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj Terminus is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

clues: Home to futuristic skyscrapers along the Bund waterfront.
This city’s skyline features a tower with a giant pink sphere.
fun_fact: Shanghai's Maglev train is the fastest commercial train in the world.
It was once a fishing village before becoming a major global port.
trivia: The Oriental Pearl Tower is one of the tallest structures in China.
Shanghai has the world's largest metro network by route length.

clues: Home to a vast Forbidden City and a nearby Great Wall.
Hosts a famous square that is among the largest public spaces in the world.
fun_fact: The Forbidden City has 9,999 rooms.
Beijing has hosted the Summer and Winter Olympics.
trivia: Peking duck is a famous culinary dish from this city.
The Temple of Heaven was where emperors prayed for good harvests.

clues: Built on the ruins of an ancient Aztec city.
Home to a giant square called the Zócalo surrounded by historic buildings.
fun_fact: Mexico City is sinking about 10 inches per year.
It has more museums than any other city in the world.
trivia: The Metropolitan Cathedral took almost 250 years to complete.
Chapultepec Park is one of the largest city parks in the Western Hemisphere.

clues: Known for classic cars, colorful buildings, and revolutionary history.
You can stroll the famous seaside avenue called the Malecón.
fun_fact: Havana was founded by Spanish settlers in the 16th century.
The city’s historic center, Old Havana, is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
trivia: Ernest Hemingway lived and wrote in Havana for nearly 20 years.
The Capitol building in Havana resembles the U.S. Capitol but is actually taller.

clues: Home to a grand castle perched on an ancient volcanic rock.
Hosts a world-famous arts festival every August.
fun_fact: J.K. Rowling wrote parts of Harry Potter in Edinburgh cafes.
The city’s Old and New Towns are both UNESCO World Heritage Sites.
trivia: The Royal Mile stretches from Edinburgh Castle to Holyrood Palace.
Edinburgh’s nickname is 'Auld Reekie,' meaning 'Old Smoky.'

clues: Home to a historic university with the Book of Kells.
Known for its lively pubs and a famous black stout beer.
fun_fact: Dublin’s name comes from the Gaelic 'Dubh Linn,' meaning 'black pool.'
The city has more than 750 pubs.
trivia: Trinity College Library is one of the largest libraries in Europe.
Dublin has produced many Nobel Prize winners in literature.

clues: The world's northernmost capital city.
Known for colorful houses and a stunning modern cathedral shaped like lava.
fun_fact: Reykjavik means 'Smoky Bay' in Icelandic.
The city uses geothermal energy to heat almost all its buildings.
trivia: Hallgrímskirkja Church is one of the tallest structures in Iceland.
Reykjavik hosts an annual celebration of the Viking heritage called Þjóðhátíð.

clues: Known for its banks, chocolate, and pristine lakeside setting.
You can explore the medieval old town, known as Altstadt.
fun_fact: Zurich consistently ranks as one of the cities with the highest quality of life.
The city is home to one of the world’s largest street parades celebrating electronic music.
trivia: The Bahnhofstrasse is one of the world’s most exclusive shopping streets.
Albert Einstein studied at Zurich's ETH University.

clues: Home to a massive fountain jetting water into the sky.
A global center for diplomacy and home to the Red Cross.
fun_fact: Lake Geneva is one of the largest lakes in Western Europe.
Geneva hosts the headquarters of the United Nations in Europe.
trivia: The Jet d'Eau shoots water 140 meters into the air.
The city has more than 30 museums and art galleries.

clues: Known as the 'City of Gold' due to its mining origins.
Close to the site where Nelson Mandela once lived.
fun_fact: Johannesburg is the largest city in South Africa by population.
It is home to the world's largest man-made forest.
trivia: The city’s Soweto township played a major role in the anti-apartheid movement.
Johannesburg has no major river or coastline.

clues: You can visit a national park with lions and giraffes right next to skyscrapers.
Known as the 'Green City in the Sun.'
fun_fact: Nairobi National Park is just 7 kilometers from the city center.
It’s one of the fastest-growing cities in Africa.
trivia: The name Nairobi comes from the Maasai phrase meaning 'cool water.'
It’s the safari capital of the world.

clues: Famous for a classic 1942 Hollywood movie set here.
Home to a grand mosque with one of the world’s tallest minarets.
fun_fact: The Hassan II Mosque can hold 25,000 worshippers inside.
Casablanca means 'white house' in Spanish.
trivia: It's Morocco's largest city and economic center.
Rick’s Café, from the movie, was later recreated as a real restaurant.

clues: Home to colonial architecture and pre-Inca ruins.
Known for its coastal cliffs and world-class ceviche.
fun_fact: Lima is the second-largest desert capital city after Cairo.
The historic center of Lima is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
trivia: Founded by Spanish conquistador Francisco Pizarro in 1535.
Miraflores district offers paragliding off seaside cliffs.

clues: Nestled between the Andes and the Pacific Ocean.
Home to a towering hilltop statue of the Virgin Mary.
fun_fact: Santiago is one of the highest capital cities in the world.
The Andes Mountains are visible from most points in the city.
trivia: Founded in 1541 by Spanish conquistador Pedro de Valdivia.
La Moneda Palace is the seat of the Chilean president.

clues: This capital lies high in the Andes, close to the equator.
You can stand with one foot in each hemisphere here.
fun_fact: Quito is the second-highest official capital city in the world.
It was the first city declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
trivia: The Middle of the World monument marks the equatorial line.
Quito’s Old Town is one of the best-preserved in South America.

clues: Home to a famous gold museum and colorful La Candelaria district.
You can ride a cable car to a mountain overlooking the city.
fun_fact: Bogotá’s Gold Museum houses over 55,000 gold artifacts.
The city sits at an altitude of 2,640 meters above sea level.
trivia: Monserrate is a pilgrimage site with panoramic city views.
Bogotá hosts the largest theater festival in the world, Festival Iberoamericano de Teatro.

clues: The most populous city in the Southern Hemisphere.
Famous for its giant avenue named after a tree: Paulista Avenue.
fun_fact: São Paulo has more helicopters per capita than anywhere else.
It’s home to the São Paulo Museum of Art, held up by red stilts.
trivia: Founded by Jesuit missionaries in 1554.
Known for its multiculturalism and massive Japanese community.

clues: A city famous for a man-made shortcut connecting two oceans.
Home to a colonial district called Casco Viejo.
fun_fact: The Panama Canal saves ships about 8,000 miles of travel.
Panama City was the first European settlement on the Pacific coast of the Americas.
trivia: The modern skyline contrasts with colonial ruins.
The city is the only capital with a rainforest within its city limits.

clues: A rapidly growing city where futuristic skyscrapers rise from the desert.
Host city for a major 2022 global sports event.
fun_fact: Doha hosted the FIFA World Cup in 2022.
The Museum of Islamic Art was designed by architect I.M. Pei.
trivia: The Pearl-Qatar is a man-made island shaped like a string of pearls.
Doha’s Corniche offers stunning waterfront views.

clues: Home to a dazzling white mosque with 82 domes.
You can visit an island full of theme parks and a Formula 1 track.
fun_fact: The Sheikh Zayed Grand Mosque can hold over 40,000 worshippers.
Ferrari World boasts the world's fastest roller coaster.
trivia: Yas Island hosts annual Formula 1 races.
Abu Dhabi is the richest emirate in the UAE.

clues: Capital city on a small island nation in the Persian Gulf.
Famous for a fort, pearl diving history, and Formula 1 races.
fun_fact: Manama means 'place of dreams' in Arabic.
The Bahrain World Trade Center uses wind turbines integrated into its design.
trivia: Bahrain Fort is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
Manama is known for hosting the Bahrain Grand Prix.

clues: A coastal city where forts guard rocky cliffs by the sea.
Known for its stunning Grand Mosque and incense markets.
fun_fact: The Sultan Qaboos Grand Mosque has one of the world’s largest chandeliers.
Muscat blends traditional Arabian architecture with modern development.
trivia: Mutrah Souq is one of the oldest markets in the Arab world.
The Royal Opera House Muscat is a major cultural landmark.

clues: Nicknamed the 'City of Sails' for its many yachts and harbors.
You can climb a dormant volcano for panoramic city views.
fun_fact: Auckland is built on a volcanic field with over 50 dormant volcanoes.
It’s the largest Polynesian city in the world.
trivia: Sky Tower is the tallest freestanding structure in the Southern Hemisphere.
Auckland was the capital of New Zealand until 1865.

clues: Known as the 'Windy City' of the Southern Hemisphere.
Home to a famous red cable car and a stunning harbor.
fun_fact: Wellington is the southernmost capital city in the world.
The city was a major filming location for The Lord of the Rings trilogy.
trivia: Te Papa Tongarewa is New Zealand’s national museum located here.
Wellington was named after the first Duke of Wellington.

clues: A sunny city famous for its river and koala sanctuary.
You can climb the iconic Story Bridge here.
fun_fact: Brisbane hosts one of the world’s largest city parks, South Bank Parklands.
The city enjoys around 283 days of sunshine a year.
trivia: Brisbane River snakes through the heart of the city.
Lone Pine Koala Sanctuary is the world's oldest and largest koala sanctuary.

clues: One of the most isolated major cities in the world.
Home to stunning beaches and a large inner-city park larger than Central Park.
fun_fact: Kings Park in Perth is larger than New York's Central Park.
Perth enjoys more hours of sunshine than any other Australian capital city.
trivia: The Swan River runs through Perth, providing scenic spots for recreation.
Rottnest Island, home to the quokka, is a short ferry ride from Perth.

clues: Capital city on a tropical island famous for Waikiki Beach.
Historic site of a major 1941 naval attack.
fun_fact: Honolulu means 'sheltered harbor' in Hawaiian.
It’s home to Pearl Harbor and the USS Arizona Memorial.
trivia: Diamond Head crater is one of Honolulu’s most famous landmarks.
Iolani Palace in Honolulu is the only royal palace on U.S. soil.

clues: Known as 'Sin City' and famous for its neon lights and casinos.
You can visit a replica Eiffel Tower and a pyramid here.
fun_fact: Las Vegas consumes over 60,000 pounds of shrimp every day.
More than 40 million visitors come to Las Vegas annually.
trivia: The Las Vegas Strip is actually located in Paradise, not Las Vegas proper.
The famous 'Welcome to Fabulous Las Vegas' sign was erected in 1959.

clues: Home to the world's most-visited amusement park.
Known for a magical kingdom and a world of movie adventures.
fun_fact: Walt Disney World Resort covers about 40 square miles.
Orlando is also known as 'The City Beautiful.'
trivia: Universal Orlando Resort is home to The Wizarding World of Harry Potter.
The city’s name comes from a soldier named Orlando Reeves.

clues: A coastal city known for its zoo and perfect weather.
You can visit historic Old Town and sunbathe on Coronado Beach.
fun_fact: San Diego has over 70 miles of beautiful beaches.
The San Diego Zoo is often ranked among the best in the world.
trivia: Balboa Park is one of the oldest public parks in the United States.
The first drive-in restaurant in the U.S. opened in San Diego.

clues: Known as the 'City of Brotherly Love' and home to a cracked bell.
You can run up famous museum steps made iconic by a boxing movie.
fun_fact: The Liberty Bell symbolizes American independence.
Philadelphia was the first U.S. capital city.
trivia: The Declaration of Independence was signed here in 1776.
The cheesesteak sandwich originated in Philadelphia.

clues: One of America’s oldest cities, famous for its Freedom Trail.
Known for its clam chowder and a giant tea protest.
fun_fact: Boston Common is the oldest public park in the U.S.
Fenway Park is the oldest major league baseball stadium still in use.
trivia: The Boston Tea Party protest took place in 1773.
The city’s nickname is 'Beantown' because of its love for baked beans.

clues: Home to the White House and the Lincoln Memorial.
You can visit a collection of museums along the National Mall.
fun_fact: Washington D.C. was designed by French architect Pierre L’Enfant.
There are no skyscrapers due to a height restriction law.
trivia: The city is not part of any U.S. state.
The Smithsonian Institution operates 21 museums in Washington D.C.

clues: Famous for a fortified wine that shares its name.
You can walk along colorful riverside buildings at the Ribeira.
fun_fact: Porto’s historic center is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
The Livraria Lello bookstore inspired parts of the Harry Potter series.
trivia: The Dom Luís I Bridge was engineered by a student of Gustave Eiffel.
Porto’s São Bento railway station is famous for its blue tile murals.

clues: Located along the French Riviera with a famous seaside promenade.
Known for its pebbled beaches and stunning Mediterranean sunsets.
fun_fact: The Promenade des Anglais was built by English aristocrats.
Nice is one of the oldest human settlements in Europe, dating back 400,000 years.
trivia: The city officially became part of France in 1860.
The Carnival of Nice is one of the world's major carnival events.

clues: Famous for its traboules, secret passageways in the old town.
Known as France’s gastronomic capital.
fun_fact: The Lumière brothers, pioneers of cinema, were from Lyon.
Lyon hosts the famous Festival of Lights (Fête des Lumières) every December.
trivia: Lyon’s Old Town is one of the largest Renaissance districts in Europe.
The city sits at the confluence of the Rhône and Saône rivers.

clues: A port city known for its vibrant Old Port and bouillabaisse.
You can visit the historic basilica of Notre-Dame de la Garde on a hill.
fun_fact: Marseille is France’s oldest city, founded by Greek sailors in 600 BC.
The Calanques, stunning limestone cliffs, are nearby.
trivia: Marseille is the second-largest city in France.
The Château d'If, a fortress on a nearby island, inspired The Count of Monte Cristo.

clues: A tiny country famous for its luxury casinos and royal family.
Home to a prestigious Formula 1 Grand Prix race through its streets.
fun_fact: Monaco is the second-smallest country in the world after Vatican City.
It has the highest per capita income in the world.
trivia: The Prince’s Palace has been the Grimaldi family’s residence since 1297.
Monte Carlo Casino helped save the Grimaldi family from bankruptcy.

clues: Known as the 'Venice of the North' for its canals.
Famous for medieval architecture and lace-making.
fun_fact: Bruges' entire historic center is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
The Belfry of Bruges leans about a meter to the east.
trivia: The city is famous for its Belgian chocolate and beer.
Bruges was one of the most important commercial cities in Europe during the Middle Ages.

clues: A major port city known for diamonds and fashion.
Home to a towering cathedral with Rubens' masterpieces.
fun_fact: Antwerp handles over 80% of the world’s rough diamond trade.
The city was heavily bombed during World War II but rebuilt beautifully.
trivia: Antwerp’s zoo, opened in 1843, is one of the oldest in the world.
The city is named after a legend involving a giant’s hand.

clues: Known for dramatic cliffs and ancient fortifications.
A tiny European capital with fairy-tale vibes.
fun_fact: Luxembourg has one of the highest GDP per capita in the world.
The Old Quarters and Fortifications are a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
trivia: Luxembourg City is one of Europe's safest cities.
The city has three official languages: French, German, and Luxembourgish.

clues: Home to Europe’s largest medieval market square.
Famous for a castle overlooking the Vistula River.
fun_fact: The legend of the Wawel Dragon is tied to Krakow.
Krakow was the royal capital of Poland until 1596.
trivia: Schindler’s factory is now a museum in Krakow.
The city’s Old Town is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

clues: Known as the 'Phoenix City' for rising from near-total WWII destruction.
Home to a reconstructed Old Town and modern skyline.
fun_fact: Warsaw’s Royal Castle was rebuilt after being destroyed in WWII.
The Warsaw Uprising Museum commemorates the 1944 rebellion.
trivia: Warsaw is Poland’s largest city and capital.
The city’s Chopin Museum honors the famous composer born nearby.

clues: Known as the 'Pearl of the Adriatic' for its stunning old town walls.
Filming location for a famous fantasy TV series.
fun_fact: Dubrovnik was an independent republic for centuries.
Its Old Town is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
trivia: The city doubled as King's Landing in Game of Thrones.
Dubrovnik’s walls stretch nearly 2 kilometers.

clues: Built around an ancient Roman emperor’s palace.
A bustling Dalmatian city facing the Adriatic Sea.
fun_fact: Diocletian's Palace is over 1,700 years old.
Split is Croatia’s second-largest city.
trivia: The Riva promenade is a lively hub in Split.
The palace complex is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

clues: A fortress overlooks the meeting point of two major rivers.
Known for vibrant nightlife and floating river clubs.
fun_fact: Belgrade’s name means 'White City'.
Kalemegdan Fortress offers panoramic views over the Danube and Sava rivers.
trivia: Belgrade is one of Europe’s oldest continuously inhabited cities.
The city has been destroyed and rebuilt more than 40 times.

clues: You can visit a golden-domed Orthodox cathedral here.
Situated at the foot of Mount Vitosha.
fun_fact: Sofia’s motto is 'Ever Growing, Never Aging.'
Alexander Nevsky Cathedral is one of the largest Eastern Orthodox churches.
trivia: Sofia has Roman ruins beneath its streets.
It’s one of the oldest capitals in Europe.

clues: Nicknamed 'Little Paris' in the early 20th century.
Home to one of the world’s heaviest buildings.
fun_fact: The Palace of the Parliament is the second-largest administrative building after the Pentagon.
Bucharest’s Arcul de Triumf resembles Paris' Arc de Triomphe.
trivia: The city has over 70,000 stray dogs historically called 'maidanezi.'
The Old Town, Lipscani, is a popular spot for cafes and nightlife.

clues: A fairy-tale Baltic capital with red rooftops and medieval towers.
Known for its walled Old Town and digital government.
fun_fact: Tallinn is one of the best-preserved medieval cities in Europe.
Estonia offers e-residency for digital nomads and businesses.
trivia: The name Tallinn may mean 'Danish Town' in Estonian.
The city was a member of the Hanseatic League.

clues: A Baltic capital with Art Nouveau buildings and cobbled streets.
Located where a famous river meets the sea.
fun_fact: Riga has the highest concentration of Art Nouveau architecture in the world.
The city’s central market is housed in old Zeppelin hangars.
trivia: Riga was founded in 1201 and is over 800 years old.
Latvia’s national flag is one of the oldest in the world.

clues: Home to the Gate of Dawn and a quirky self-declared republic.
This city once had one of the largest Jewish populations in Europe.
fun_fact: Vilnius’ Užupis district declared itself an independent republic.
The city’s Old Town is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
trivia: Vilnius was once known as the 'Jerusalem of the North.'
The city has over 40 churches in its historic center.

clues: A Nordic capital known for its design, saunas, and sea-facing architecture.
You can take a ferry to a massive sea fortress nearby.
fun_fact: Suomenlinna Fortress, a UNESCO site, lies across six islands.
Helsinki hosted the Summer Olympics in 1952.
trivia: The city was designed in a neoclassical style inspired by St. Petersburg.
Helsinki has more saunas than cars.

clues: You can ski just minutes from the city center in this fjord-side capital.
Known for its Viking history and Nobel Peace Prize ceremonies.
fun_fact: The Nobel Peace Prize is awarded annually in Oslo City Hall.
Oslo was previously called Christiania.
trivia: The city is surrounded by forests and has more than 40 islands.
Vigeland Sculpture Park features over 200 statues by one artist.

clues: Built on 14 islands, connected by over 50 bridges.
You can visit a museum dedicated to a 17th-century shipwreck.
fun_fact: The Vasa Museum houses a preserved warship that sank in 1628.
Stockholm is known as the 'Venice of the North.'
trivia: Stockholm's Gamla Stan is one of Europe’s best-preserved old towns.
It’s home to the annual Nobel Prize banquet.

clues: A capital where bicycles outnumber cars.
You can visit a famous statue of a fairy tale mermaid here.
fun_fact: Copenhagen’s Tivoli Gardens inspired Walt Disney to create Disneyland.
The Little Mermaid statue is based on Hans Christian Andersen's story.
trivia: Nyhavn is known for its colorful harbor-side buildings.
Copenhagen ranks as one of the world’s happiest cities.

clues: A coastal city with canals, seafood markets, and a massive amusement park.
This city hosts an international film festival each year.
fun_fact: Gothenburg is home to Liseberg, the largest amusement park in Scandinavia.
The city’s tram network is the most extensive in Northern Europe.
trivia: It was founded in 1621 by King Gustavus Adolphus.
Gothenburg is known as Sweden’s 'second city.'

clues: Known for oil, fjords, and colorful wooden houses.
Close to a famous rock that juts out over a cliff.
fun_fact: Stavanger is called the 'Oil Capital of Norway.'
Nearby Pulpit Rock offers breathtaking views over the Lysefjord.
trivia: The city center features Europe’s best-preserved wooden houses.
Stavanger hosts the annual international food festival 'Gladmat.'

clues: This city grew from a fishing village to a tech giant in just 40 years.
Located just across the border from Hong Kong.
fun_fact: Shenzhen is considered China’s Silicon Valley.
It was China’s first Special Economic Zone, established in 1980.
trivia: Shenzhen is home to the headquarters of Tencent and Huawei.
The city has one of the busiest container ports in the world.

clues: Famous for spicy hotpot and cuddly black-and-white animals.
Capital of a province known as the land of abundance.
fun_fact: Chengdu is home to the world-famous Giant Panda Breeding Research Base.
The city is the origin of Sichuan cuisine.
trivia: Chengdu was one of the first cities to use paper money.
It’s one of China’s most laid-back cities, known for teahouses and slow living.

clues: A southern Chinese port city once called Canton.
Known for dim sum and a tall TV tower shaped like a twisted rope.
fun_fact: Guangzhou has hosted the Canton Fair since 1957.
The Canton Tower stands at 600 meters tall.
trivia: The city has over 2,000 years of trading history.
It’s the third-largest city in China by population.

clues: Formerly known as Saigon, it's the economic heart of Vietnam.
You can explore war museums and French colonial buildings.
fun_fact: It was renamed after revolutionary leader Ho Chi Minh in 1976.
Ben Thanh Market is one of the oldest surviving landmarks.
trivia: Motorbikes dominate traffic here, with over 8 million in use.
The Cu Chi Tunnels nearby were used during the Vietnam War.

clues: A city of lakes, temples, and a preserved Old Quarter.
Capital city known for its egg coffee and puppet theaters.
fun_fact: Hanoi’s name means 'City inside the river.'
Hoan Kiem Lake features a legendary turtle tower.
trivia: The Temple of Literature is Vietnam’s first university.
Hanoi blends French colonial, Chinese, and Southeast Asian influences.

clues: Home to a golden stupa towering over the city skyline.
Former capital with colonial-era architecture and busy street markets.
fun_fact: Shwedagon Pagoda is over 2,500 years old and plated in gold.
Yangon has the most colonial buildings in Southeast Asia.
trivia: The city was formerly known as Rangoon.
The circular train offers a 3-hour local city loop experience.

clues: Gateway to ancient temples swallowed by jungle.
Near a massive complex with faces carved in stone towers.
fun_fact: Angkor Wat is the largest religious monument in the world.
Siem Reap means 'Siam Defeated' in reference to past conflicts.
trivia: The temples attract over 2 million tourists each year.
Lara Croft: Tomb Raider was filmed at Ta Prohm temple here.

clues: Located at the junction of three rivers, including the Mekong.
You can visit the Royal Palace and a chilling genocide museum.
fun_fact: The name Phnom Penh means 'Penh's Hill'.
The city was once called the 'Pearl of Asia.'
trivia: The Tuol Sleng Genocide Museum was once a high school.
The Silver Pagoda inside the Royal Palace complex has a floor made of silver tiles.

clues: A megacity on an island nation, with a historic walled city at its heart.
Known for jeepneys, karaoke, and colonial charm.
fun_fact: Intramuros is a Spanish-era fortress district in Manila.
Manila is one of the most densely populated cities in the world.
trivia: The city was heavily damaged in World War II and rebuilt.
Rizal Park is named after the country’s national hero, José Rizal.

clues: A chaotic and vibrant capital on the island of Java.
You can visit the National Monument at the city's center.
fun_fact: Jakarta was formerly known as Batavia under Dutch rule.
The city is gradually sinking due to groundwater extraction.
trivia: It’s the largest city in Southeast Asia by population.
Jakarta is often plagued by flooding during the rainy season.

clues: Known for its rice terraces, Hindu temples, and beach resorts.
An island paradise that's also a hub for yoga and surf culture.
fun_fact: Bali’s airport is named after Ngurah Rai, a national hero.
Denpasar is the island's capital and cultural center.
trivia: Bali is the only Hindu-majority province in Indonesia.
The island celebrates Nyepi, a day of silence, each year.

clues: A bustling port city on the Arabian Sea and Pakistan’s financial hub.
Home to a giant mausoleum of the nation's founder.
fun_fact: Karachi was once the capital of Pakistan.
The city’s population exceeds 15 million, making it one of the world's largest cities.
trivia: Mazar-e-Quaid is the tomb of Muhammad Ali Jinnah.
Clifton Beach is one of the most popular seaside attractions in the city.

clues: Known for its vibrant culture, Mughal architecture, and poetic heritage.
You can visit a majestic fort next to a beautiful mosque with pink domes.
fun_fact: The Lahore Fort and Shalimar Gardens are UNESCO World Heritage Sites.
The city is considered Pakistan's cultural capital.
trivia: Minar-e-Pakistan stands where the Pakistan Resolution was passed in 1940.
Lahore is home to the iconic Badshahi Mosque, built in 1673.

clues: A city of seven hills and ancient Roman ruins.
Modern cafes and souks thrive next to a historic citadel.
fun_fact: The Amman Citadel contains ruins from Roman, Byzantine, and Umayyad eras.
It was once known as Philadelphia in ancient times.
trivia: The Roman Theater in downtown Amman can hold 6,000 spectators.
The Dead Sea lies just 45 minutes west of the city.

clues: An ancient rose-red city carved into rock cliffs.
You reach its entrance through a narrow gorge called the Siq.
fun_fact: Petra was the capital of the Nabatean Kingdom.
It was unknown to the Western world until 1812.
trivia: Al-Khazneh (The Treasury) is Petra’s most famous monument.
It’s one of the New Seven Wonders of the World.

clues: A city sacred to three major world religions.
Home to a golden-domed shrine and ancient limestone walls.
fun_fact: The Old City of Jerusalem is divided into four quarters: Jewish, Muslim, Christian, and Armenian.
The Western Wall is a revered site for Jewish prayer.
trivia: The Dome of the Rock is one of the oldest Islamic structures in the world.
Jerusalem is mentioned over 800 times in the Bible.

clues: A modern city known for tech startups and Mediterranean beaches.
Famous for its Bauhaus architecture and nightlife.
fun_fact: Tel Aviv has more vegan restaurants per capita than any other city.
The White City, a collection of Bauhaus buildings, is a UNESCO site.
trivia: The city was founded in 1909 on sand dunes.
It’s considered Israel’s financial and cultural capital.

clues: A coastal city with Roman ruins and a long, storied past.
Known as the 'Paris of the Middle East' for its culture and fashion.
fun_fact: Beirut has been destroyed and rebuilt seven times.
The city is home to the American University of Beirut, founded in 1866.
trivia: The National Museum of Beirut showcases Lebanon’s ancient history.
Martyrs’ Square is a historic center of political and cultural life.

clues: A Eurasian capital nestled between mountains and thermal springs.
You can ride a cable car to a fortress overlooking colorful balconies.
fun_fact: Tbilisi means 'warm place' due to its hot springs.
The city was founded in the 5th century AD.
trivia: The Narikala Fortress offers panoramic views of the Kura River.
Old Tbilisi features a unique blend of European and Asian architecture.

clues: Once the capital, now the cultural heart of a vast Central Asian country.
Set at the base of snow-capped mountains and famous for apples.
fun_fact: The name 'Almaty' means 'full of apples.'
It’s located near the world’s largest high-mountain skating rink: Medeu.
trivia: The city was Kazakhstan’s capital until 1997.
Zenkov Cathedral is one of the tallest wooden buildings in the world.

clues: Known as the political capital of Africa and headquarters of the African Union.
Home to ancient manuscripts, coffee culture, and mountain views.
fun_fact: Addis Ababa sits at over 2,300 meters above sea level.
Lucy, the famous hominid fossil, was discovered in Ethiopia and displayed here.
trivia: The city's name means 'New Flower' in Amharic.
Addis Ababa University hosts the Institute of Ethiopian Studies and Ethnological Museum.
